newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakh 1996 chrome/ferro alloys output plunges.
newsitem.headline: Kazakh 1996 chrome/ferro alloys output plunges.

text.p: Kazakhstan's national chrome company Kazkhrom, whose main shareholder is Japan Chrome Corp., said on Friday that Kazakh chrome ore mine output plunged 54 percent in 1996 to 1.1 million tonnes.
Kazkhrom President Akzam Bayandarov also told Reuters that Kazkhrom's 1996 output of ferro-alloys, including those of chrome, fell by 23.8 percent to 548,800 tonnes.
He said the company had been hit by unfavourable international metals prices and fierce competition and losses on world markets in the wake of the bankruptcy of commodities trader AIOC Corp.

"We expected this (losses) to happen, because the presence of a large, integrated company like Kazkhrom on the international market, has, naturally, led to opposition from those firms which started working in this market long ago," he also said.
Offshore Japan Chrome owns a 55.2 percent stake in Kazkhrom, which groups mines, smelters and other related plants.
Japan Chrome is registered in the British Virgin Islands and industry officials have said London-based Trans-World Group has an interest in Kazkhrom.
Kazakhstan's chrome ore reserves are estimated to be the second largest in the world, and Kazkhrom groups all of Kazakhstan's chrome mines and plants.
Bayandarov said Kazkhrom ended 1996 with losses of 126 million tenge after profits in 1995 of 8.12 billion tenge, but said he hoped for a turnaround this year.
He said the company was considering shedding ferro-alloy units not integrated with an ore base and that it had broadened its range of alloys.
Kazkhrom suspended chrome ore shipments to Russian ferro-alloy factories from May 1996 but has continued deliveries to Russian chemical plants.
Bayandarov said 250,000 tonnes of chrome ore were exported last year to Russian chemical plants but that ore would be delivered to Russian ferro-alloy plants only if they prepaid.
